name: My Health Record - Security, Privacy and Access
:LABEL: Curriculum
description: Understand the security, privacy and access rules when using My Health Record in general practice

name: My Health Record System Definition and Core Functions
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define My Health Record as a secure online summary of an individuals key health information stored in Australia;List the types of information accessible through My Health Record including shared health summaries, discharge summaries, prescription and dispense records, pathology and diagnostic imaging reports, and immunisation history;Explain that My Health Record enables information sharing between healthcare providers to support continuity of care and clinical decision-making;Describe the difference between viewing existing information and uploading new documents to a patients record;Identify that use of My Health Record is not mandatory for every patient encounter and requires clinical judgement
description: Understanding my health record system definition and core functions: Define My Health Record as a secure online summary of an individuals key health information stored in Australia

name: Healthcare Identifiers and Correct Patient Matching
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define Individual Healthcare Identifier (IHI) as the unique number that links a person to their My Health Record;Explain the purpose of Healthcare Provider Identifier - Individual (HPI-I) and Healthcare Provider Identifier - Organisation (HPI-O) in secure system access;Describe how incorrect patient identification can lead to privacy breaches and clinical safety risks;Identify the Healthcare Identifiers Service as the system that manages and verifies healthcare identifiers;Explain the importance of verifying patient identity and IHI before accessing or uploading information to My Health Record
description: Understanding healthcare identifiers and correct patient matching: Define Individual Healthcare Identifier (IHI) as the unique number that links a person to their My Health Record

name: Permitted Access Purposes and Prohibited Behaviours
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define providing healthcare as the only lawful purpose for accessing a patients My Health Record;Identify prohibited access scenarios including curiosity access, checking records of family or friends, pre-employment screening, and insurance or medico-legal purposes without proper authority;Explain that administrative tasks directly supporting patient care such as appointment preparation or care coordination constitute providing healthcare;Describe the requirement to document the clinical reason for each access to My Health Record;Given five scenarios, correctly determine whether accessing My Health Record is permitted and justify the decision using the providing healthcare test
description: Understanding permitted access purposes and prohibited behaviours: Define providing healthcare as the only lawful purpose for accessing a patients My Health Record

name: Consumer Privacy Controls and Restricted Access Workflows
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Explain the difference between record access codes that restrict the entire record and document access codes that restrict specific documents;Describe the workflow for requesting and using an access code from a patient including how to document the interaction;Identify what information is visible to healthcare providers when a record or document is restricted;Explain the limitations of restricted access controls in genuine emergency situations and organisational policies for such scenarios;Describe how to respond when a patient requests information be hidden or removed from their record including the distinction between provider actions and consumer actions
description: Understanding consumer privacy controls and restricted access workflows: Explain the difference between record access codes that restrict the entire record and document access codes that restrict specific documents

name: Legislative Framework Governing My Health Record
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify the My Health Records Act 2012 as the primary legislation governing collection, use and disclosure of information in My Health Record;Explain that the Privacy Act 1988 including the Australian Privacy Principles applies to all private health service providers using My Health Record;Describe the Healthcare Identifiers Act 2010 as governing the use of IHI, HPI-I and HPI-O for system access;Recognise that the My Health Records Rule 2016 and associated regulations provide detailed operational requirements;Apply the correct legislative instrument to determine obligations in a given scenario involving access, disclosure or security
description: Understanding legislative framework governing my health record: Identify the My Health Records Act 2012 as the primary legislation governing collection, use and disclosure of information in My Health Record

name: Australian Privacy Principles Application to My Health Record
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Explain that APP 11 requires healthcare providers to take reasonable steps to protect personal information from misuse, interference, loss, unauthorised access, modification or disclosure;Describe how the APPs govern the entire information lifecycle from collection through to secure disposal;Identify that reasonable steps for security must be determined based on the sensitivity of information, possible consequences of breach, and current security standards;Explain transparency requirements under the APPs including informing patients about My Health Record access and uploads;Recognise that APP compliance is assessed by the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner and may result in enforcement action
description: Understanding australian privacy principles application to my health record: Explain that APP 11 requires healthcare providers to take reasonable steps to protect personal information from misuse, interference, loss, unauthorised access, modification or disclosure

name: State and Territory Privacy Legislation Interaction
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify that NSW, Victoria and ACT private sector health providers must comply with both Commonwealth and state or territory privacy laws;Explain that the Privacy Act 1988 does not apply to state and territory public hospitals but does apply to all private providers regardless of location;Recognise that some jurisdictions have specific requirements for notifiable diseases and sensitive health information that may affect My Health Record uploads;Describe where to direct privacy inquiries for public sector agencies in NSW, Queensland, Northern Territory, Tasmania and Victoria
description: Understanding state and territory privacy legislation interaction: Identify that NSW, Victoria and ACT private sector health providers must comply with both Commonwealth and state or territory privacy laws

name: Organisational Security and Access Policy Requirements
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify that a written My Health Record Security and Access Policy is legally required before registering with the system and applies to all organisations including sole practitioners;List the mandatory policy components including authorisation processes, access deactivation procedures, training requirements, identity verification, physical and information security measures, and risk mitigation strategies;Explain that the policy must be reviewed at least annually and whenever new or changed risks are identified;Describe how the policy must address circumstances requiring immediate access suspension including staff departure, role changes, and suspected account compromise;Recognise that the policy must align with Rule 42 of the My Health Records Rule 2016
description: Understanding organisational security and access policy requirements: Identify that a written My Health Record Security and Access Policy is legally required before registering with the system and applies to all organisations including sole practitioners

name: Practical Information Security Controls for Healthcare Organisations
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify essential security controls including unique strong usernames and passphrases for each staff member, automatic software updates, anti-virus protection, and multi-factor authentication where available;Explain workstation security requirements including automatic screen locks, session timeouts, and controls for shared terminals;Describe secure remote access requirements for telehealth and off-site work including VPN use and endpoint security;Identify backup requirements including frequency, off-site secure storage, and protection from ransomware through network isolation;Explain the principle of least privilege access and role-based access controls for My Health Record;Describe secure handling of My Health Record information when printing, emailing or storing in local clinical systems
description: Understanding practical information security controls for healthcare organisations: Identify essential security controls including unique strong usernames and passphrases for each staff member, automatic software updates, anti-virus protection, and multi-factor authentication where available

name: Responsible Officer and Organisation Maintenance Officer Roles
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify that the Responsible Officer or Organisation Maintenance Officer is legally responsible for authorising and managing staff access to My Health Record;Explain the requirement to disable access immediately when staff leave the organisation, change roles, or when an account is compromised;Describe the RO and OMO responsibility for ensuring compliance with the organisations My Health Record Security and Access Policy;Identify the process for verifying staff identity before authorising access and communicating verified identities to the System Operator;Explain record-keeping requirements for access authorisations, modifications and deactivations
description: Understanding responsible officer and organisation maintenance officer roles: Identify that the Responsible Officer or Organisation Maintenance Officer is legally responsible for authorising and managing staff access to My Health Record

name: Staff Training and Competency Requirements
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify that all staff must complete My Health Record training before first access as required by organisational policy;List essential training content including legislative requirements, permitted access purposes, consumer controls, security obligations, and breach reporting;Explain the requirement for regular refresher training at least annually or when significant system or policy changes occur;Describe methods for assessing and documenting staff competency in My Health Record security and privacy requirements;Identify the joiners, movers and leavers process including training for new staff, retraining for role changes, and access removal for departing staff including contractors and locums
description: Understanding staff training and competency requirements: Identify that all staff must complete My Health Record training before first access as required by organisational policy

name: Access Methods and Operational Workflows
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify the three methods for accessing My Health Record: conformant clinical software, hospital applications, and the National Provider Portal;Explain the governance differences between integrated clinical software access and standalone portal access including audit trail visibility;Describe appropriate use cases for administrative staff access including appointment preparation and care coordination;Identify the requirement for National Authentication Service for Health (NASH) PKI certificates to enable secure connection between clinical software and My Health Record;Explain the need for a NASH PKI certificate policy addressing certificate management, renewal and security
description: Understanding access methods and operational workflows: Identify the three methods for accessing My Health Record: conformant clinical software, hospital applications, and the National Provider Portal

name: Uploading Information and Document Quality Obligations
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Explain the principle of information minimisation when uploading documents to My Health Record including only necessary and relevant information;Identify situations where uploading may not be appropriate including unverified information, draft documents, and highly sensitive information the patient wishes to keep private;Describe considerations for uploading information about sensitive topics including family violence, sexual health, mental health, and care of minors;Explain the requirement to ensure uploaded documents are accurate, complete and clinically relevant before upload;Identify the healthcare providers responsibility to discuss My Health Record uploads with patients and respect their preferences
description: Understanding uploading information and document quality obligations: Explain the principle of information minimisation when uploading documents to My Health Record including only necessary and relevant information

name: System Operator Security Assurance and Protective Measures
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Explain that the Australian Digital Health Agency operates My Health Record in accordance with the Australian Government Protective Security Policy Framework;Identify at least three security assurance activities used by the System Operator including penetration testing, vulnerability scanning, and security audits;Describe the protections provided by encryption in transit and at rest, access controls, and continuous monitoring;Explain that audit trails maintained by the System Operator record all system activity for operational purposes, audits and investigations;Recognise that System Operator security measures do not remove the requirement for healthcare organisations to implement local security controls
description: Understanding system operator security assurance and protective measures: Explain that the Australian Digital Health Agency operates My Health Record in accordance with the Australian Government Protective Security Policy Framework

name: Detecting and Responding to Unauthorised Access
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify indicators of potential unauthorised access including access outside normal working patterns, access to records of staff or family members, and high volumes of record access;Explain the immediate containment steps when unauthorised access is suspected including account suspension, password reset, and preventing further access;Describe the assessment process to determine the scope and impact of a suspected breach including reviewing audit logs and identifying affected individuals;Recognise that both the healthcare organisation and the System Operator monitor for suspicious access patterns;Identify the requirement to document all steps taken in response to suspected unauthorised access
description: Understanding detecting and responding to unauthorised access: Identify indicators of potential unauthorised access including access outside normal working patterns, access to records of staff or family members, and high volumes of record access

name: Notifiable Data Breaches Scheme and Mandatory Reporting
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define an eligible data breach under the Privacy Act 1988 as unauthorised access or disclosure likely to result in serious harm;Explain the 30-day assessment period to determine if a suspected breach is likely to result in serious harm;Identify the requirement to notify the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner and affected individuals when an eligible data breach occurs;Describe mandatory notification requirements to the System Operator under the My Health Records Act when breaches involve My Health Record;List the information that must be included in breach notifications including the nature of the breach, the information involved, and steps individuals should take
description: Understanding notifiable data breaches scheme and mandatory reporting: Define an eligible data breach under the Privacy Act 1988 as unauthorised access or disclosure likely to result in serious harm

name: Breach Response Procedures and Incident Management
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Demonstrate the six-step breach response process: detect, contain, assess, notify, remediate, and document;Explain the requirement to have documented breach response procedures including escalation pathways and access to technical and legal advice;Describe remediation actions following a breach including system security improvements, additional staff training, and policy updates;Identify scenarios requiring immediate breach response including shared login credentials discovered, receptionist curiosity access, and locum access not deactivated after departure;Explain the importance of conducting a post-incident review to identify root causes and prevent recurrence
description: Understanding breach response procedures and incident management: Demonstrate the six-step breach response process: detect, contain, assess, notify, remediate, and document

name: Enforcement Bodies and Consequences of Non-Compliance
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner as the regulator of the Privacy Act 1988 with powers to investigate complaints and enforce compliance;Explain that the Australian Digital Health Agency as System Operator can investigate suspected breaches and take enforcement action including access suspension;Describe potential professional consequences through AHPRA including conditions on registration, suspension or cancellation for serious breaches;Identify civil penalties available under the Privacy Act and My Health Records Act for serious or repeated privacy breaches;Recognise that unauthorised access may also constitute criminal offences under Commonwealth or state legislation
description: Understanding enforcement bodies and consequences of non-compliance: Identify the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner as the regulator of the Privacy Act 1988 with powers to investigate complaints and enforce compliance

name: Clinical Governance Compliance Monitoring and Audit Programs
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Design an audit program specifying frequency of access reviews, sampling methodology, red flags requiring investigation, and escalation pathways;Identify audit activities including regular review of access logs, verification that access aligns with patient appointments or clinical care, and investigation of anomalies;Explain documentation requirements for audit programs including audit plans, findings, investigations, corrective actions and evidence of resolution;Describe the integration of My Health Record compliance monitoring into broader practice information governance and clinical risk management frameworks;Develop key performance indicators for My Health Record compliance including training completion rates, policy review currency, audit completion, and incident response times
description: Understanding clinical governance compliance monitoring and audit programs: Design an audit program specifying frequency of access reviews, sampling methodology, red flags requiring investigation, and escalation pathways

name: Resources and Support for Compliance
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify key OAIC resources including the Guide to Health Privacy, Guide to Securing Personal Information, and APP 11 guidance on security of personal information;Locate Australian Digital Health Agency resources including the My Health Record system security requirements, conformance testing information, and provider support materials;Explain how RACGP standards and general practice accreditation requirements align with My Health Record security and privacy obligations;Identify sources of technical advice for security incidents including IT service providers, cyber security consultants, and the Australian Cyber Security Centre;Describe where to access legal advice on privacy obligations including privacy lawyers, professional indemnity insurers, and professional colleges
description: Understanding resources and support for compliance: Identify key OAIC resources including the Guide to Health Privacy, Guide to Securing Personal Information, and APP 11 guidance on security of personal information
